Mindflayer.synopsis: The player approaches the dying mind flayer. During the dialog the player describes how the mind flayer still tries to telepathically dominate him or her into feeling compassion for the creature. In the end the player can give in to the mind flayer (which results in death) or resist.

PAD_FirstIntellectDevourerCombat.synopsis: Start of a player's turn. The first time this player (and nearby players, if any) are in combat with Intellect Devourers. Intellect Devourers are lethal at close range. Keep in mind player might be alone.

VB_SawMindflayer.synopsis: The party remarks when seeing people trying to dig somebody out of the wreckage in the chaos of the nautiloid crash site

PAD_SeeWoundedDevourers.synopsis: You meet with some Intellect Devourers: walking brains essentially that are nasty creatures. They attack you. As non-gith you have no idea what these things are. As gith, you know very well.

VB_OtherSurvivors.synopsis: The party remarks on seeing footprints.

AD_KilledMindflayer.synopsis: The party comments after killing the mind flayer that lay dying in the wreckage.

automatic_ordering.reasoning:
Analyzing the session synopses reveals two main narrative threads. In one thread the player comes upon a mind flayer at the nautiloid crash site. First, the party observes activity around the wreckage (VB_SawMindflayer), which suggests someone (or something) is being dug out. This observation then leads to the encounter where the player actively approaches the dying mind flayer (Mindflayer). At that point the player has a choice – either succumb to the mind flayer’s telepathic persuasion (a path leading to character death) or resist and then kill the creature. If the player chooses to kill it, a later session (AD_KilledMindflayer) is triggered in which the party comments on its death. Since the death branch happens only if the mind flayer is killed, the sessions “Mindflayer” and “AD_KilledMindflayer” are mutually exclusive in a given playthrough (the dialogue with the living mind flayer versus the aftermath of killing it).

The other thread concerns encounters with Intellect Devourers. The session PAD_FirstIntellectDevourerCombat is triggered at the start of combat with these lethal creatures. Later, depending on circumstances (and in particular for characters familiar with them, such as gith), the player may encounter wounded devourers in a non-combat or different context (PAD_SeeWoundedDevourers). Thus, logically the combat encounter should come before the wounded-devourers session.

The session VB_OtherSurvivors, which simply comments on seeing footprints, appears to be an ambient narrative detail without a strict dependence on the other key events.

Based on this analysis, ordering constraints exist between VB_SawMindflayer -> Mindflayer and Mindflayer -> AD_KilledMindflayer (with the added note that the latter is an alternative branch) and between PAD_FirstIntellectDevourerCombat -> PAD_SeeWoundedDevourers. The mutual exclusiveness is noted between the Mindflayer dialogue branch and the aftermath branch AD_KilledMindflayer, meaning that only one of these paths will occur in a single narrative run.

Mindflayer_6.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_6.text: *You approach the dying monster. This is the thing that abducted you.*

Mindflayer_41.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_41.text: *You could end its life here and now, if only you didn't feel...*

Mindflayer_31.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_31.context: NodeContext: Bewildered. That was the last emotion you were expecting.

Mindflayer_61.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_61.text: *The poor creature is on the brink of death, but there's still time.*
Mindflayer_61.context: NodeContext: The mind flayer has you under its control now, you earnestly mean this line.

Mindflayer_25.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_25.text: *You'd give your life to save it, to nurse it back to health!*
Mindflayer_25.context: NodeContext: The mind flayer has you under its control now, you earnestly mean this line.

Mindflayer_9.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_9.text: *But then the feeling slips. The creature's mind seems to focus elsewhere.*
Mindflayer_9.context: NodeContext: With a bit of relief that the mind flayer's focus on you is abating.

Mindflayer_47.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_47.text: *Your minds fuse, lusting for something that is... gone.*
Mindflayer_47.context: NodeContext: Mysterious. What is it? What is gone?

Mindflayer_45.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_45.text: *But then its grip claws back with a vengeance: a vice locking your mind into obedience.*

Mindflayer_39.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_39.text: *It needs sustenance to survive, and with your very body you can provide.*
Mindflayer_39.context: NodeContext: You're being enthralled again. Giving up yourself up as food sounds like a sensible idea.

Mindflayer_33.speaker: Player
Mindflayer_33.text: Submit to the feeling - lean in, as for a kiss...

Mindflayer_23.speaker: Lae'zel
Mindflayer_23.text: K'chakhi - back. You must resist its call!

Mindflayer_48.speaker: Shadowheart
Mindflayer_48.context: NodeContext: Alarm - her companion's at risk of becoming enthralled by a mind flayer

Mindflayer_20.speaker: Karlach
Mindflayer_20.text: Whoa - what  in the hells are you doing?!

Mindflayer_8.speaker: Player
Mindflayer_8.text: No. It's fine. Everything will be fine...

Mindflayer_43.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_43.text: *Warm, wet tentacles wrap themselves around your head, and for the first time in your life...*
Mindflayer_43.context: NodeContext: Accepting. This is a good, wonderful thing.

Mindflayer_17.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_17.context: NodeContext: With wonder. You feel glorious. Your life is complete.

Mindflayer_22.speaker: Player
Mindflayer_22.text: Change your mind. Resist, if you still can.

Mindflayer_55.speaker: Astarion
Mindflayer_55.text: What in the hells - get away from that thing!
Mindflayer_55.context: NodeContext: Asking "What in the hells are you doing?" - realises halfway through the line that you're going to kiss a mind flayer

Mindflayer_27.speaker: Wyll
Mindflayer_27.text: What are you... no, no! You have to fight it!

Mindflayer_51.speaker: Gale
Mindflayer_51.text: What are you doing? Stand back! Now!

Mindflayer_5.speaker: Player
Mindflayer_5.text: Resist the intrusion with everything you have.

Mindflayer_49.speaker: Player
Mindflayer_49.text: Draw on your willpower. Improvise a mental shield against the creature's hungry mind.

Mindflayer_0.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_0.text: *You feel the creature's thoughts stumble against your magic, your will to resist...*

Mindflayer_35.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_35.text: *Your willpower is not enough. The creature's mind slaps away your efforts to resist it.*

Mindflayer_7.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_7.text: *Its mind grips your own like a vice. You feel it locking you into obedience.*

Mindflayer_46.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_46.text: *You try to break through, but its mind is impenetrable. With a last surge of defiance, it slaps your efforts away.*

Mindflayer_57.speaker: Player
Mindflayer_57.text: Take advantage of the lapse - break free.

Mindflayer_62.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_62.text: *The monster lies exhausted, defeated. Its eyes - wet, orange pearls - radiate malice.*

Mindflayer_1.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_1.text: *You can't move, can't think: thinking is mercifully done for you.*
Mindflayer_1.context: NodeContext: The mind flayer has you under its control now, you earnestly mean this line.

Mindflayer_15.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_15.text: *It will be a joy to serve - to die for it an honour!*
Mindflayer_15.context: NodeContext: The mind flayer has you under its control now, you earnestly mean this line.

Mindflayer_58.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_58.text: *It's possessing your mind, forcing you to... love it.*
Mindflayer_58.context: NodeContext: With a hint of desperation

Mindflayer_14.speaker: Player
Mindflayer_14.text: No. You should be furious... shouldn't you?

Mindflayer_34.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_34.text: *Yes, you feel hate. And you deserve to be punished for it.*
Mindflayer_34.context: NodeContext: The mind flayer has you under its control now, you earnestly mean this line.

Mindflayer_44.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_44.text: *You should be whipped - made to bow before this creature in shame!*
Mindflayer_44.context: NodeContext: The mind flayer has you under its control now, you earnestly mean this line.

Mindflayer_30.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_30.text: *The monster's tentacles twitch weakly. It won't last much longer.*

Mindflayer_56.speaker: Narrator
Mindflayer_56.text: *You approach the dying ghaik. The foul thing is at your mercy, and you would have its head.*
Mindflayer_56.context: NodeContext: ghaik is 'gayk' the githyanki word for a mind flayer - this line is only spoken by githyanki characters

PAD_FirstIntellectDevourerCombat_0.speaker: Player
PAD_FirstIntellectDevourerCombat_0.text: Better stay back. One strike could be lethal.

VB_SawMindflayer_0.speaker: Player
VB_SawMindflayer_0.text: There! A mind flayer - and it's hurt.

VB_SawMindflayer_1.speaker: Player
VB_SawMindflayer_1.text: Even injured, it's dangerous. Be careful.

PAD_SeeWoundedDevourers_1.speaker: Player
PAD_SeeWoundedDevourers_1.text: More of the mind flayers' pets.
PAD_SeeWoundedDevourers_1.context: NodeContext: Pleased, anticipating coming face to face with his prey

VB_OtherSurvivors_0.speaker: Player
VB_OtherSurvivors_0.text: Footprints. There may be even more that survived the crash.

AD_KilledMindflayer_0.speaker: Player
AD_KilledMindflayer_0.text: Monster. Death is too good for it.

AD_KilledMindflayer_1.speaker: Player
AD_KilledMindflayer_1.text: For the best. Death is too good for it.
AD_KilledMindflayer_1.context: InternalNodeContext: In case the mind flayer dies because a player tried to heal/help him.
